Method Detail

convert

public java.lang.String convert(java.lang.String num,
                                int from,
                                int to)
This method converts a number from one base to another

This does it by splitting the original number into an array of digits, and then finding the decimal representation of the number by raising each digit to a power. It then will convert it to the new base by taking repeated divisions and their remainders, until the number is less than one. I know that there already exists a way to do this, with toString(int i, int radix), and parseInt(String s, int radix), but I wanted to do it using as few built-in functions as possible. After it is done, it reverses the string, since the characters are appended back-to-front.

Parameters:
num - The number, represented as a String, that you want to convert from one base to another
from - The base that the number is currently represented in. Must be between 2 and 36
to - The desired destination base. Must be between 2 and 36
Returns:
A string with the number in the desired destination base
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the bases are not between 2 and 36, or if there is a number that is not represented in the base specified

toBase10

public int toBase10(java.lang.String num,
                    int from)
This program converts a string encoded in a specified base to a base 10 integer

This works in the exact same way that conversion works, except it converts it into an integer instead of a String.

Parameters:
num - The number, represented as a string, that you want to convert to base 10
from - The starting base
Returns:
The base 10 representation of the given number

encodeASCII

public java.lang.String encodeASCII(java.lang.String ASCII,
                                    int to)
This method encodes an ASCII string in a specified base

This works by splitting the string into its characters, then converting the characters into its ASCII integer, and then encoding that into a base. It is then padded into the correct number of characters so it can be decoded. For example, each base 2 number will be exactly 8 characters long, with leading zeros

Parameters:
ASCII - The string in ASCII you want to convert
to - The destination base
Returns:
A string with a series of numbers that will decode to the ASCII string

decodeASCII

public java.lang.String decodeASCII(java.lang.String numbers,
                                    int from)
This method decodes an ASCII string given a specified base that it was encoded in

Since we know the base, we will just split the string into strings of whatever length it was calculated with. We get this by performing the operation floor(log(128)/log(base)+1)
Since all the ASCII characters used here are under 128, which is 2^7, each base 2 string will be 8 characters long at max, so we make all of the base 2 strings 8 characters long so that we can split them.

Parameters:
numbers -
from -
Returns:
An ASCII string with the encoded message
